TL;DR, I highly, highly recommend playing this game, but I do not recommend buying it. This is one of the coolest concepts I have ever seen destroyed by an unusable DRM scheme.

From Dust is a work of art. Watching the form of the earth change and mould as the player manipulates it brings back memories of Black and White, but with a sense of visual awe that comes from being a much more recent game. It is something that I feel any gamer owes it to themselves to experience at least once. Sadly, I can't recommend buying the game, as I have an ethical objection to UPlay. The alternative, a Chrome app that is free in the Chrome Store, is okay, but ultimately Ubisoft's disingenuity has ruined, or at least limited access to, what I consider to be an actual art piece.

Fun fact: Ubisoft actually patched the game to remove UPlay. I had been hoping that would happen and bought it shortly after. Only a few months later, I had been happily enjoying my new game when I launched one day to find UPlay had been patched back in.

Ubisoft, I know you're not listening, but stop punishing your customers for buying your products. You did the right thing once before and removed the DRM from this game. Now that the DRM is back on, I would not be surprised to find the number of seeders for this game on torrent sites has spiked. reviewText:
First of all this game will require Uplay to play and you will have to lock your serial to that one account so don't forget the information. While annoying, this is doable and not the only game like it. Wish I had read more of the steam reviews before buying. I would not recommend this game and if you already bought it, my sympathies, but it is not the next Black and White. Buy at own risk, I cannot stress this enough.

Controls and Mechanics: Saw a lot of complaints about this. Some buttons are counter intuitive or not 'the norm' but you can grow accustomed to them fairly quickly there's only two really weird ones. UI is spare so you aren't overwhelmed with options. Movement of the cursor corresponds with the movement of your avatar and 90% of the time this is fine and you get used to it fast. The other 10% of the time it will go too far too fast or something at just the wrong time and Bad Things will happen because of it (this has caused me to restart at least one map). Similarly 1-2-3-4 isn't hard to remember, but when the powers attributed to them shift around you have to constantly check the menu to make sure you're using the right power.

The AI of the people is actually fairly decent - when it works. When it doesn't you get dozens of annoying little voices screaming at you from the top of a hastily erected pillar as rivers of lava flow around them, voices which you cannot stop until either that lava does, or one of your powers comes up, etc. Furthermore idiotic people have cost me wins before, causing me to have to restart some maps several times or making simple tasks very hard.

Camera: Similar to dungeon crawlers, up above and slightly behind the avatar with the option to zoom in a little or to zoom in completely (and not be able to do anything) on just one of your humans. Like the controls 90% of the time this is fine, but when it goes wrong it can be very frustrating giving the fast liquids you are working with.

Now to the reason I am writing this review: some spoilers ahead (I try not to name names).




Surprisingly interesting premise and I genuinely wanted to see my people through and to find out more about what had happened before me. The cut scene between maps gets annoying overtime since its pretty long and just the same footage over and over again but that's not game breaking. What is game breaking is the end. The last level. First of all the game froze just as I was about to complete it so I had to go back and do it all over again (first time this had happened). I hesitate to detail what exactly happens but suffice to say that I was extraordinarily displeased, felt that absolutely NONE of the plot points were tied up (they didn't even try to softball something in or if they did it was too subtle for my shock and disappointment to see it), we weren't given any revelations or massive info dumps, its one giant screw you to the idiot stupid enough to waste their time on this game. Before the end I was willing to give this game a pass and say there were some levels worth redoing, some content worth getting every little bit from, but afterwards I uninstalled the game without second thoughts.

And ultimately yes, the levels (what few there are) are well designed.

But that brings me to my first complaint: There are only 12 levels (not counting the finale which doesn't really count since you can easily win simply by not using anything but the Breath of Earth.) For a full priced game, this is scaled more as a tech demo and paying full price is outrageous. (And I mean that to be a bit dramatic, because Fromt Dust is offensively short.)

It took me roughly 6 hours to beat the game (And I had to play at least three maps over.)

reviewText:
Really awesome until the last few levels. Before the later stages, it was relaxing, like playing in a sandbox, yet reasonably challenging without being frustrating or punishing.

Unfortunately, as I got to the later stages, difficulty arose due to a certain totem being placed in a very tricky, high and near-lava location. You have to rely on the individual pathing of the AI, but there's not much indication if they'll be able to get up slopes (when there's multiple potential routes to a location) so trying to get them to this totem without having them try to cross lava is an exercise in frustration. The AI pathing tends to be annoying to deal with as the stages get harder. Also, depending on how you may have tried to build walls in stages with lava, you may find yourself having spent a lot of time on a stage but in a sitation where you'll have to try to destroy some walls to let your villagers get to a totem. Doing this is tedious because you need to use explosive plants (if you made rock walls). I don't understand the point in letting players manipulate something in such a tedious way instead of providing a less time-consuming method.

Overall, dealing with the lava is quite frustrating, especially with how it can completely wipe out villages if so much as a particle touches some of your greenery. I understand having a challenge makes things more fun, but the way this challenge is presented is more frustrating than entertaining, because a small mistake can reset your entire stage progress.

Slight variation on the level design and the lava mechanics would've probably made the game fun, but as it is I can't recommend it because of the unpleasantness of the later levels. Challenge should not come from dealing with the stupid AI, and mistakes shouldn't make you feel like you've just wasted a bunch of time, because that's no fun. Towards the end it just became not pleasant to play anymore. It's a shame because the sandbox mechanics are very entertaining to interact with - it's almost like they weren't sure whether they wanted to frustrate players with hard challenges or provide a relaxing, slow-paced sandbox game.

reviewText:
It's like a smaller scale Black & White, without a giant animal. The goal is to guide your tribe to the right place(s) while protecting them from natural disasters. It's all up to you, as long as you can protect them. But it gets challenging pretty fast.
The graphics are pretty sweet, especially for a downloadable game. It definitely has a nice style. The sounds are very well done as well.
All in all, it's a game I would recommend. There aren't that many 'God sim' games around these days, so From Dust is a great addition to anyone's collection.

reviewText:
From Dust is the last game from Eric Chahi (known for Another World and Heart of Darkenss). COntrary to his most famous creations which were side scrolling adventures, From Dust is a God-game.

To make this review short, I thoroughly enjoyed it and I spent about 18 hours with the main missions, not touching the challanges, so it has plenty of content to keep you satisfied. Plus the game looks amazing. The only gameplay-related minus is the lack of a sandbox mode, but that's alleviated by the fact that the last mission is exactly that: a sandbox mode. Though I think it should have been a separate mode, not locked at the end of the campaign.

Now, to speak a bit about its technical problems. I will start by saying that I had absolutely no problem with any of the problems most people bring up when talking about From Dust, and I wholeheartedly recommend it.
Its most common problems are:
- bad mouse and keyboard controls. I was not affected as I played with a gamepad. If you own a gamepad (and most PC users do nowadays), do yourself a favor and play this game with it. It wills ave you a lot of frustration and it will help you enjoy the game.
- locked framerate. Yes, the game is locked at 30fps and there are no excuses but: it hasn't bothered me at all since this is an incredibly slow paced game. In this case 30fps is completely acceptable and doesn't realy break the game or the immersion in any way.
- uPlay. Everyone and their mother are complaining about uPlay. It didn't bother me at all, and to be honest I don't see how anyone that isn't a kid would be bothered by it. It is just another UI layer that didn't bother me at all. It just loads with the game and remains in the background while I play. Just like steam. To be bothered by one but not by the other is completely immature in my opinion.
- Always online DRM. By the time I played this game, Ubisoft removed always online DRM so right now this is a non-issue.

If you like god-games, do yourslef a favor and play From Dust. It's not really as good as the pold Populous games (nostalgia may be a factor in my case), but it is still pretty good and offers a lot of content. The game is also pretty cheap nowadays (you can get it in a sale for 5 dollars or euros).

BUT, the mouse controls suck. I'm four levels in and I still hate how the mouse controls. I regularly pick up water instead of the dirt I want that's next to it. Directing my people to a new spot is hard because getting the mouse to settle on that spot is hard. There's some really weird acceleration going on. And the game forces me to use uPlay. Despite my admission that I shouldn't have bought this game, I think this paragraph still warrants a thumbs down, because I tried to enjoy it for what it is and these frustrations stopped that.

reviewText:
I had a good few days invested into this game because, you know, I like to take my time with new concepts, especially if they are pretty.  This game has a lot to offer in terms of beauty and inspiring animations where it comes to the forced generated into the environments.
The problem is that this game feels like it was supposed to be more, couldn't reach its high-end goals, and so settled for being a simple puzzle game.  I wanted to care about the little tribes people, but, because I could really do nothing more meaningful with them than build them paths and tell them to go somewhere, they never really became all that endeared to me.  I mean if they had even been better programmed to be more interactive just with one another and their environments, it would have been sufficient for me to feel like an actual all-powerful god watching over my people.  Fact is, they just threw up cookie-cutter village spheres and then sat around waiting for me to do something.  I would have greatly enjoyed watching them fish and farm and hunt or just about anything which made them feel alive to the gamer.  I really think that, with the bare bones nature of your godly influence in the world of From Dust, this game needed more content and variety within its little living world.
Anyway, going from scripted event to scripted event works well enough for a FPS or arcade modes in other genres, but it does very little for a game like this, in my mind and while many of the natural disasters you are trying to aid your little pointless people in surviving are rather glorious, they actually leave you, a god, feeling rather small and futile when faced with their might and splendor.
I wouldn't really recommend this game for more than a cursory playthrough and a few moments of drooling over the fluid physics.  It's pretty, but its pretty blank as well.

reviewText:
I love this game. It has fantastic atmosphere and it just looks and feels great. It is a story that is not directly put in words or told to you. It is an experience. A journey.

You act as a god of a tribe assisting them in their search for their ancestors. The gameplay is really interesting and is based entirely on modifying the terrain in various ways and it works really well. The gameplay revolves around grabbing materials and objects and moving them elsewhere. It sounds boring when described but it very satisfying in-game.

There are also tsunamis that cover the entire map, and spontaneous volcanoes to mess up your finely tuned plans. Sometimes the game gets seriously difficult. I remember trying to beat a few levels for several hours.

The graphics are stunning and it has good replayability. I've played the game through twice and it's really easy to pick up waste a few hours every once in a while. After you beat the game you unlock a sandbox mode where you can create your own small world. (So much fun!)

It seems that Steam did not record all those hours (~40) I've played this game.

reviewText: From Dust delivers excellent gameplay that's easy to learn yet amazingly addictive, making it one of the best simulators out there. The story itself shows that the developers did their research, keeping things simple while showcasing the characters' cultural development. The main story has thirteen levels with an ending that fits; this seeming brevity is more than made up for by replay value and the challenge mode's sheer variety of levels. Thinking is definitely required for this game, as is good timing. Remember: it's okay to restart a level if you feel like you made a mistake - that's why the restart option is there.
This is literally a sandbox game.  It's am amusing diversion and showcases some excellent water and geological physics, but in a practical sense it only makes me wish I was playing Black & White.

Interesting idea; infuriating execution.  Definitely worth trying on the cheap for the cleverness of the central gameplay idea, but wonky controls, impossible physics, and AI vacilating between suicide and catatonia will have you tearing your hair out in the later levels.

It's a pretty short game and I don't think it has a lot of replay value, but if it's on sale, you should really give it a go. Reminds me a little of Black & White, but without battles or an economy. Your foes are fire/lava & water/tsunamis.\n\nAnyhoo, I had fun with it :-)

The gameplay is essentially a puzzle-based god game, where you control the elements earth, lava and water and are able to give basic directions to a handful of villagers in order to help your tribe survive. Levels generally focus on one or two problems building up - an incoming flood, or an impending volcanic eruption - and require you to take action to protect your village from the same.

The game is, though, far too short. It feels more like a tutorial campaign. What little is there is very nice, with great music and atmosphere. For now, this is a great game that's on sale often enough, and is definitely worth a shot when it's at about half the asking price.

Let me start by saying: From Dust is not a god-game and shouldn't be considered as such. Although you can't slap your people on the face, drown them intentionally or crush their homes and dreams (well, you can, but then it's game over) From Dust does have similarities to these titles. It has puny little humans and an omnipotent player that controls the surroundings and as such, indirectly also these puny little people. And it is beautiful and it has a physics engine unlike any other game. But in my view, From Dust is most reminicent of Lemmings: guide your people (the puny little humans) to safety via manipulation of the world around them. Raise the earth to create a bridge over water or drain a pond. And it is actually pretty cool. A bit repetitive in the long run perhaps, but a nice niche game.

From Dust brings the term sandbox game into a whole new meaning.  You are literally dropped into a giant side box.  A sandbox that you can control and manipulate in order to help your tribesmen find the promised land.  Developed by Ubisoft, and release in August of 2011.  From Dust gives you god like powers over the elements.

The premise here is simple.  With your various powers over the sand, wind, water and fire, guide your tribe from totem to totem in order to unlock a portal to the next zone.  Each level gradually introduces you to new powers and concepts.  The first few levels are pretty straight forward and act as tutorials to help you develop an understanding for the game's basic mechanics and controls.  You can literally take your godly hand and scoop up areas of terrain, or water, or even lava to mold and manipulate the land.


As you proceed farther into the game, these powers are used not only to lead your tribe forward, but also to protect them from the earth itself.  Whether it's fire, floods, giant waves or massive eruptions, you must continually alter the earth in order to keep your tribe safe.  This is where the interaction of the various powers comes to fruition.  Though sand can be piled up and prevent waves of water from flooding the area, the force of the water can eventually erode the sand away.  Combining lava and sand can create rock to solve this problem, but accidentally redirecting lava in the wrong direction can be even deadlier.

This balance of powers, and the addition of various power ups as well map unique quantities like hidden underground springs and other surprises keep you adapting often.  The maps often adapt as well.  Several levels in From Dust change part way through and throw new obstacles your way.  In a first play through these events create greater challenges as now your well planned out modifications to the world need to quickly be changed before your tribe is flooded, or burned alive.


The look and feel of the earth and it's elements is also just a lot of fun to play with.  Terraforming the earth with your various powers is intuitive and the elements react in fairly realistic way.  Water and lava combine into clouds of steam, cooling into ever growing mounds of rock.  Rivers slowly cut their way through sand at the lowest points creating rivers and peninsulas.  It's truly a wonder to just play in the sandbox that is From Dust just to see what will happen.


Throughout all this, a charming story of the cycle of life unfolds.  From Dust is definitely a game you want to give a full play through of to gain the full experience.  The beautiful graphics and physics hold up today against more modern games.  The story, though a relatively simple one of life and death is told mostly visually as you proceed from level to level.  This is a great game, and a gem to try if you have a chance.

On paper, the concept behind From Dust is filled with promises. A simulator where you can manipulate terrains on a whim? Groundbreaking! But despite its enormous potential, this title ends up offering too little.

From Dust is no more a simulator than it is a puzzle. In its (short) story mode, you are tasked with occupying totems scattered throughout several islands. Your opposition comes from the destructive forces of storms, tsunamis, and magma. Against these, you must utilize your godlike abilities to construct a safe haven.

Outside the campaign are dozens of challenge maps. Here, you are given a limited set of abilities with which you'll use to accomplish an objective, be it migrating tribes or saving them from extinction.

Once the campaign and challenges are completed, that's it. There is little to no reason to replay this game unless you really enjoyed it. The unreleased map editor would've gone a long way to making this a lasting title, but alas, it isn't one.

PRO:
The primary mechanic of manipulating the land is wonderfully executed. Every level is creative and interesting and I never felt like I was just repeating the level before it. This game gets top marks for game design.

Furthermore, the presentation is top notch. The water and lava flow beautifully and everything is tied together nicely with a distinct visual style.

CON:
The problem with this game mainly comes from the fact that it was designed for consoles and poorly adapted for PCs. The mouse vertical/horizontal axes control a little pointer that tracks the terrain rather than the screen, making it needlessly difficult to click things on uneven ground.

The game is also filled with unskippable cutscenes. Between levels you repeatedly watch the same cutscene. The scene is only about 60 second longs, but it's still annoying. Also, periodically in a level the game takes control of your camera to slowly pan around the new objective, even if you've played that level before and already seen the cutscene. It breaks the flow of the game and, worse yet, the world doesn't pause for the cutscene. I've lost villages while my camera was seized from me. It's not the end of the world, but it's a ridiculous thing for a game studio to overlook.

This combined with the mouse issue leaves me sorely disappointed in Ubisoft's user interface design. Do they have a QA department?

There's also no real story to speak of. You just follow a tribe around different levels. The lack of story doesn't seriously detract from the game, but a quality story or just some kind of world building would have certainly added to it.

SUMMARY:
That said, the game is still engaging and unique. It's short*, but that's just because it's all quality content that they didn't pointlessly recycle (unlike 90% of all other games out there). If you really want more after the story"

reviewText:
From Dust is an entertaining game that stands out from similar civilization-type games in that you have to craft the land to assist and protect your native people as they go from increasingly inhospitable locations in an effort to find their Ancients who created their world. The story is basic (and not the focus of the game) and there are no real characters besides your virtually identical-looking natives and the only narrative is that which you hear at the begining of each stage. However the voice-over does stand out as it is spoken in a Bahasa Indonesian language that is neat to listen to and don't worry, there are subtitles in English.
The real fun comes from the gameplay where you gather up sand, lava, water and more in an effort to keep your people alive and help them to build and maintain their villages in ridiculously dangerous environments such as within the crater of an active volcano, hot damn! These scenarios can defintely be challenging as you will be forced to stop and think in order to plan the best course of terrain alteration or disaster will befall your villagers and you'll be forced to re-examine your strategy or even re-start the stage.
I also have to point out the level of realism attached to the various elements in that lava flows like you'd expect, water from tsunamis flows down from elevated portions of the land to pool in recesses, etc. Thanks to this you'll really feel like you're crafting a believable world and perhaps even learn to appreciate how difficult it must be for certain people (both past and present) to struggle against the elements.

PRO:
The primary mechanic of manipulating the land is wonderfully executed. Every level is creative and interesting and I never felt like I was just repeating the level before it. This game gets top marks for game design.

Furthermore, the presentation is top notch. The water and lava flow beautifully and everything is tied together nicely with a distinct visual style.

CON:
The problem with this game mainly comes from the fact that it was designed for consoles and poorly adapted for PCs. The mouse vertical/horizontal axes control a little pointer that tracks the terrain rather than the screen, making it needlessly difficult to click things on uneven ground.

The game is also filled with unskippable cutscenes. Between levels you repeatedly watch the same cutscene. The scene is only about 60 second longs, but it's still annoying. Also, periodically in a level the game takes control of your camera to slowly pan around the new objective, even if you've played that level before and already seen the cutscene. It breaks the flow of the game and, worse yet, the world doesn't pause for the cutscene. I've lost villages while my camera was seized from me. It's not the end of the world, but it's a ridiculous thing for a game studio to overlook.

This combined with the mouse issue leaves me sorely disappointed in Ubisoft's user interface design. Do they have a QA department?

There's also no real story to speak of. You just follow a tribe around different levels. The lack of story doesn't seriously detract from the game, but a quality story or just some kind of world building would have certainly added to it.

SUMMARY:
That said, the game is still engaging and unique. It's short*, but that's just because it's all quality content that they didn't pointlessly recycle (unlike 90% of all other games out there). If you really want more after the story"
